 CANCER (MALIGNANT NEOPLASM), COLORECTAL (COLON CANCER)
 HYPOXEMIA
 .H/O DIABETES MELLITUS (DM), TYPE II
 .H/O ALCOHOL ABUSE

   Assessment: This is a 63 year-old male with a history of DM2, HTN, HLP,
   ETOH abuse, obesity, OSA on CPAP who is transferred to the ICU for
   hypoxia s/p laparoscopic sigmoidectomy and coloproctostomy
   Plan:
   # Hypoxia: most likely etiology is volume overload in the setting of
   IVFs intra and postoperatively.  ECHo recently done with normal EF.
   ECG without concerning findings, but likely given his h/o of HTN, has a
   component of diastolic dysfunction not well seen on suboptimal ECHO.
   He has been persistently hypertensive and tachycardic.  No fevers or
   leukocytosis or cough to suggest PNA.  Not an aspiration risk at this
   time. other possibility includes PE given malignancy and recent surgery
   though patient has been on hep sc for ppx.  He does also have sinus
   tachycardia. also, could be post op atelectasis. Most likely seems to
   be pulmonary edema.
   -maximize control of BP and HR with labetalol IV. Will d/c metoprolol
   IV
   -f/u final read CTA
   - NRB for now
   - can try CPAPfor hypoxia, though could benefit from bipap given the
   hypercarbia
   - lasix 80 mg IV BID- goal I/O -1 to -2L in 24H. RPT pm lytes
   - repeat CXR in AM
   - sputum culture if possible
   - incentive spirometry
   - NEBS prn
   # Hypercarbia: likely due to OSA, hypoventilation/obesity.  Unclear
   what baseline is, but given elevated bicarb, likely is a chronic
   retainer
   - hold off on BIPAP for now
   - diuresis as above
   - incentive spirometry
   # Hypertension/tachycardia: unable to take POs at this time.
   Peristently hypertensive and tachycardic.  Likely from not taking home
   meds; pain, and possibly component of ETOH withdrawal
   - cont hydral 20 IV q6H. D/C metoprolol and start labetalol as above.
   # h/o ETOH abuse; on lorazepam CIWA, still shaky on exam but has not
   needed benzos for CIWA >10 while in the unit.
   - increase lorazepam to 1 mg Q1H CIWA
   # Colonic adenocarcinoma s/p lap sigmoidectomy: on PCA for pain control
   without a basal rate
   - f/u surgery recs
   - wound care per surgery
   - d/w surgery re when he can start POs; consider peeling off on PCA
   once able to take POs
   # DM2: NPO for now
   - regular ISS
   # Hyperlipidemia: hold home meds for now
   # FEN: NPO for now
   - replete lytes; [**Hospital1 7**] given diuresis
   # Access: PIVs
   # PPx: hep sc
   # Code: FULL
   # Dispo: ICU for now
   # Comm: patient
 will try to contact son and/or dtr for update today
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO for now
   Glycemic Control:  Regular insulin sliding scale
   Lines:
   18 Gauge - [**2115-1-30**] 12:50 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Boots, SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:ICU
Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, ethanol abuse, obesity, and obstructive sleep apnea who was transferred to the ICU for hypoxia after undergoing a laparoscopic sigmoidectomy and coloproctostomy. The patient is currently stable on non-rebreather oxygen but bipap has been unsuccessful. He has mild back pain, no shortness of breath, or other pain. The patient's vital signs are within normal limits, with a temperature of 37.4°C (99.3°F), heart rate of 99 bpm (normal range: 80-110 bpm), blood pressure ranging from 125/44mmHg to 154/69mmHg, respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute (normal range: 20-26 breaths per minute), and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient's heart rhythm is sinus rhythm, and he has no murmurs. The patient is overweight and obese with no acute distress. Physical examination findings include symmetric chest expansion, clear breath sounds, soft and non-tender abdomen with bowel sounds present, and purposeful movement with normal tone. Neurologic examination reveals an attentive patient who follows simple commands, responds to verbal stimuli, and has normal muscle tone. 

Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 14.4 K/uL, hemoglobin of 10.8 g/d

   Assessment: This is a 63 year-old male with a history of DM2, HTN, HLP,
   ETOH abuse, obesity, OSA on CPAP who is transferred to the ICU for
   hypoxia s/p laparoscopic sigmoidectomy and coloproctostomy
   Plan:
   # Hypoxia: most likely etiology is volume overload in the setting of
   IVFs intra and postoperatively.  ECHo recently done with normal EF.
   ECG without concerning findings, but likely given his h/o of HTN,
   likely has a component of diastolic dysfunction not well seen on
   suboptimal ECHO.  He has been persistently hypertensive and
   tachycardic.  No fevers or leukocytosis or cough to suggest PNA.  Not
   an aspiration risk at this time. other possibility includes PE given
   malignancy and recent surgery though patient has been on hep sc for
   ppx.  He does also have sinus tachycardia. also, could be post op
   atelectasis
   - NRB for now; repeat ABG
   - can try CPAP, though likely would benefit from bipap given the
   hypercarbia
   - lasix 80 mg IV BID- goal I/O -1 to -2L in 24H
   - control HR/BP as below
   - repeat CXR in AM
   - CTA for r/o PE once stable and can lie flat; clinical suspicion for
   PE is low, would not start on empiric heparin unless BP drops or
   clinically unstable otherwise
   - sputum culture if possible
   - incentive spirometry
   - NEBS prn
   # Hypercarbia: likely due to OSA, hypoventilation/obesity.  Unclear
   what baseline is, but given elevated bicarb, likely is a chronic
   retainer
   - attempt BIPAP as tolerated
   - diuresis as above
   - incentive spirometry
   # Hypertension/tachycardia: unable to take POs at this time.
   Peristently hypertensive and tachycardic.  Likely from not taking home
   meds; pain, and possibly component of ETOH withdrawal
   - increased hydral to 20 IV q6H and metoprolol to 10 IV q6h.  titrate
   up as tolerated
   - if difficult to control, can consider labetalol for rate/BP control;
   can consider nitro gtt or nicardipine gtt
   - cycling cardiac enzymes per surgery
   - repeat ECG in AM
   # h/o ETOH abuse; on lorazepam CIWA, still shaky on exam
   - increase lorazepam to 1 mg Q1H CIWA
   # Colonic adenocarcinoma s/p lap sigmoidectomy: on PCA for pain control
   - f/u surgery recs
   - wound care per surgery
   - d/w surgery re when he can start POs; consider peeling off on PCA
   once able to take POs
   # DM2: NPO for now
   - regular ISS
   # Hyperlipidemia: hold home meds for now
   # FEN: NPO for now
   - replete lytes; [**Hospital1 7**] given diuresis
   # Access: PIVs
   # PPx: hep sc

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, ethanol abuse, obesity, and obstructive sleep apnea who underwent a laparoscopic sigmoidectomy and coloproctostomy. He is currently in the ICU due to hypoxia post-surgery. His vital signs are stable, but he is hypertensive and tachycardic. The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count. His electrolyte levels are within normal range. The assessment indicates possible hypoxia due to volume overload, diastolic dysfunction, or postoperative atelectasis. The plan includes continuing non-rebreather oxygen, repeating ABG, trying CPAP or bipap, administering lasix to control fluid balance, controlling heart rate and blood pressure, and considering a CT angiogram for pulmonary embolism.

Potential medical complications that can arise:
1. Respiratory complications: The patient may experience further respiratory distress or develop pneumonia due to his history of OSA and recent surgery.
2. Cardiac complications: Given the patient's history of hypertension, there is a risk of cardiac dysfunction or heart failure.
3. Thromboembolic events: Considering the patient's malignancy and recent surgery, there is a possibility of developing deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism.
4. Wound infection or dehiscence: The patient's surgical wound

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, ethanol abuse, obesity, and obstructive sleep apnea. He was admitted to the ICU for hypoxia after undergoing a laparoscopic sigmoidectomy and coloproctostomy. 

On the first day, the patient was initially on labetalol and hydralazine for blood pressure and heart rate control but was later switched to metoprolol and hydralazine. The patient's vital signs showed a temperature of 36.7°C, heart rate of 104 bpm, blood pressure of 125/82 mmHg, respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 93%. The patient's physical examination revealed diaphoresis, crackles in the lungs, and an distended abdomen. 

The patient's laboratory results showed elevated white blood cell count, hematocrit, and blood glucose levels. The assessment plan included addressing the patient's hypoxia, hypercarbia, hypertension, and tachycardia. The possible etiologies for the hypoxia were volume overload, pulmonary embolism, postoperative atelectasis, or pulmonary edema. The plan involved maximizing control of blood pressure and heart rate, following up with a final read CTA, using nonrebreather mask for now, and trying CPAP for hypoxia.

Potential

   ETOH abuse, obesity, OSA on CPAP who is transferred to the ICU for
   hypoxia s/p laparoscopic sigmoidectomy and coloproctostomy
   Plan:
   # Hypoxia: most likely etiology is volume overload in the setting of
   IVFs intra and postoperatively.  ECHO recently done with normal EF.
   ECG without concerning findings, but likely given his h/o of HTN, has a
   component of diastolic dysfunction not well seen on suboptimal ECHO.
   He has been persistently hypertensive and tachycardic.  No fevers or
   leukocytosis or cough to suggest PNA.  Not an aspiration risk at this
   time. other possibility includes PE given malignancy and recent surgery
   though patient has been on hep sc for ppx.  He does also have sinus
   tachycardia. also, could be post op atelectasis. Most likely seems to
   be pulmonary edema.
   -maximize control of BP and HR-meds changed from IV to Metoprolol 25 Q
   8 PO and Captopril 12.5 Q 8 PO today
   -f/u final read CTA
   - NRB for now- wean as tol
   -Recheck pm ABG
   - If decompensates, can try CPAP for hypoxia, though could benefit from
   bipap given the hypercarbia
   - lasix 80 mg IV BID- goal I/O -1 to -2L in 24H.
   - repeat CXR in AM
   - sputum culture if possible
   - incentive spirometry
   - NEBS ATC
    # Hypercarbia: likely due to OSA, hypoventilation/obesity.  Unclear

   - hold off on BIPAP for now
   - diuresis as above
   - incentive spirometry
   # Hypertension/tachycardia: Peristently hypertensive and tachycardic.

   withdrawal
   - Metoprolol and captopril PO as above.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, alcohol abuse, obesity, and obstructive sleep apnea.
- He was admitted to the ICU for hypoxia after undergoing laparoscopic sigmoidectomy and coloproctostomy.
- The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.7°C (98.1°F), heart rate of 104 bpm, blood pressure of 125/82 mmHg, respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 93%.
- The patient's physical examination revealed diaphoresis, crackles in the respiratory system, distended abdomen, and no cyanosis.
- Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and glucose levels, as well as decreased platelet count and creatinine levels.
- The patient's most likely etiology for hypoxia is volume overload due to intravenous fluids given intra and postoperatively.
- Plan includes maximizing control of blood pressure and heart rate, weaning off non-invasive ventilation, repeating arterial blood gas analysis, and diuresis with Lasix.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Pulmonary Edema: The patient's hypoxia may be caused by pulmonary edema, which can result from fluid overload and cardiac dysfunction.
2. Pneumothorax/Embolism: The patient's history of malignancy and

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, alcohol abuse, and obesity. He was admitted to the ICU for hypoxia after undergoing a laparoscopic sigmoidectomy and coloproctostomy. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.6°C, heart rate of 117 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 192/78 mmHg to 200/94 mmHg, respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 90%. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with high-flow nasal cannula.

24-hour events:
- The patient's arterial line was started at 07:09 PM.
- The patient was given metoprolol and captopril, initially through intravenous (IV) administration but later switched to oral (PO) dosages.
- The patient experienced hypercapnia in the afternoon, which improved after a trial of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP).
- Furosemide was discontinued because the patient's contraction alkalosis was believed to be driving respiratory acidosis.
- Acetazolamide 500 mg IV was administered.
- The patient's beta blocker medication was titrated up.
- An arterial blood gas (ABG) test was conducted at 6:00 am on [**2115-2-1**].
